Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: Religious Infusion and Asymmetric Group Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will examine how differences in religious ritual, doctrine, and context shape the motivations and capacities of groups in which religion permeates many aspects of private and public life, sometimes leading those groups to initiate conflict against stronger groups. The project will enhance basic understanding about religion, ethnicity, and conflict by testing hypotheses about different mechanisms through which religion may shape conflict. It will extend and integrate theoretical perspectives in political science, economics, anthropology, and social psychology that connect religion and conflict. It also will assess the motivations and processes though which some religiously infused, low-power groups engage in asymmetrical conflict against groups that seemingly are much more powerful. The project will help fill a significant gap in knowledge for U.S. and international agencies and organizations by providing insights and information regarding the ways in which groups differ in their religious infusion and how these differences translate into group conflict. These insights will assist policy makers and practitioners in identifying factors that create or mitigate conflicts. As recent events have demonstrated, enhanced understanding of the causes, facilitators, and inhibitors of asymmetric conflict between groups having great disparity in power has great significance for enhancing the national security of the U.S. and other nations. The project also will provide interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for students in a range of different settings.

The investigators will conduct this project using three complementary methods in order to test nine hypotheses about the ways through which differences in religious ritual, doctrine, and context affect the motivations and capacities of weak, religiously infused groups to initiate conflict against stronger groups. They will conduct case studies comparing two transnational Muslim ethnic groups in the Middle East and South Asia (the Kurds in Iran, Iraq, Syria, and Turkey and the Baluchi in Iran, Afghanistan, and Pakistan). They will conduct qualitative comparative analyses of 40 relatively resource-weak groups around the world, and they will conduct laboratory-based experimentation in the U.S. and India. These approaches will elucidate the factors shaping the circumstances in which resource-poor, religiously infused groups engage in asymmetric conflict, and they will facilitate identification of the circumstances in which religious infusion may lead to more peaceful outcomes. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why do the weak sometimes attack the strong? It is no surprise that groups with greater power and resources are willing to engage in conflict with their weaker counterparts. Yet some weak groups violently engage much more powerful groups—undeterred by their significant resource constraints, and at the risk of incurring great costs. Why? And what role might religion play in leading these comparatively low-power groups (e.g., terrorist groups, ethnic groups, or even states) to engage in violent action against more powerful groups?

This project tested a set of theoretically-motivated hypotheses about the role of specific aspects of religion in explaining why weak groups might sometimes attack strong groups. Taking a multi-disciplinary approach, we employed methods ranging from laboratory experiments to transnational case studies to a global expert survey to (1) test novel hypotheses about the causal mechanisms through which religiously-infused, low-power groups engage in conflict against more powerful groups, (2) extend and integrate theory in political science, economics, anthropology, and social psychology connecting religion and conflict. Added benefits included the development of an empirical approach in which methods from multiple research traditions inform causal inferences and conclusions, and the creation of a unique dataset on religion and asymmetric conflict.

In a highly controlled experiment, we found that low-power male groups (compared to male dyads, or female groups or dyads) were especially likely to perpetrate extreme aggression against higher-power (size- and sex-matched) groups, and that this was especially the case for male groups for whom a common religious identity had been engaged. These findings provide the first evidence that religious infusion can cause low-power groups to use extreme aggression against much more powerful groups.

In another experiment, we found that such religiously-infused males were especially likely to engage in extreme self-sacrificial aggression—that is, aggression that harmed themselves personally—when prompted to think about receiving afterlife rewards that were contingent upon behaving prosocially specifically toward the ingroup (but not when thinking about afterlife rewards contingent upon behaving prosocially in a broader, more general way). These findings are consistent with the hypothesis that religious infusion causes intergroup conflict to the extent that it activates a tribal “we-focused” psychology.  

Case studies yielded a new variable, that of religious leadership and its legacy, that has been largely neglected in the field of political science. We think this finding will add to the field's understanding of the role of religion in conflicts, even conflicts that appear secular in nature. 

The expert-based surveys about disadvantaged groups around the world provide evidence that, contrary to expectations,religiously infused groups are not necessarily more violent than other groups, nor more willing to sacrifice themselves for the protection of sacred sites. These findings call for further research, that we are undertaking, to understand differences in the experiment findings and the cross-national findings.

Beyond these contributions of intellectual merit, this project created significant broader impacts. It has provided significant training and professional development for graduate students, including opportunities to learn new experimental methods, questionnaire design and online survey software, along with qualitative research strategies. The graduate students constitute an integral part of the project, one is participating as a co-author in analyzing results and presenting and writing up findings. The PI and co-PIs have played an active role in mentoring the graduate students through workshops, conferences and networking. Four of the Research Assistants recently completed their doctorates, with one taking a very good position in a private firm, another a tenure-track position at a research university, one taking a post-doc at an NGO, and another taking a post-doc at a major research university.
